factoid: Natásha was one of the first people to meet Prince Andrew.
Natásha was wearing a dark‑blue house dress.
Prince Andrew thought Natásha even prettier in her dark‑blue house dress than in her ball dress.
Natásha and the Rostóv family welcomed Prince Andrew as an old friend, simply and cordially.
Prince Andrew had formerly judged the Rostóv family severely.
Prince Andrew now saw the Rostóv family as consisting of excellent, simple, and kindly people.
The old count’s hospitality and good nature struck Prince Andrew especially in Petersburg as a pleasant surprise.
Prince Andrew could not refuse to stay to dinner because of the old count’s hospitality and good nature.
Prince Andrew thought that the Rostóv family are capital people who have no idea what treasure they possess in Natásha.
Prince Andrew thought that the Rostóv family are kindly folk and form the best possible setting for Natásha, a strikingly poetic, charming girl overflowing with life.
In Natásha, Prince Andrew was conscious of a strange world completely alien to him.
The strange world was brimful of joys unknown to Prince Andrew.
The strange world had already begun to disconcert Prince Andrew in the Otrádnoe avenue and at the window that moonlight night.
After entering the strange world, Prince Andrew found a new enjoyment.
The strange world was no longer alien to Prince Andrew.
The strange world no longer disconcerted Prince Andrew.
After dinner, Natásha went to the clavichord and began singing at Prince Andrew’s request.
Prince Andrew stood by a window talking to the ladies and listened to Natásha.
During a phrase, Prince Andrew ceased speaking and suddenly felt tears choking him.
Prince Andrew had thought that feeling tears choking him was impossible for him.
Prince Andrew looked at Natásha as she sang, and something new and joyful stirred in his soul.
Prince Andrew felt happy and at the same time sad.
Prince Andrew had absolutely nothing to weep about yet he was ready to weep.
Prince Andrew wondered about his former love, the little princess, his disillusionments, and his hopes for the future.

The chief reason for Prince Andrew’s emotional state was a sudden vivid sense of the terrible contrast between something infinitely great and illimitable within him and that limited and material something that he and even Natásha were.
This contrast weighed on and yet cheered Prince Andrew while Natásha sang.
After Natásha finished singing, she went up to Prince Andrew and asked how he liked her voice.
Natásha felt confused, feeling that she ought not to have asked it.
Prince Andrew smiled at Natásha and said he liked her singing as he liked everything she did.
Prince Andrew left the Rostóv family’s house late in the evening.
Prince Andrew went to bed from habit, but soon realized that he could not sleep.
Prince Andrew lit a candle, sat up in bed, then got up, then lay down again, not at all troubled by his sleeplessness.
Prince Andrew’s soul was as fresh and joyful as if he had stepped out of a stuffy room into God’s own fresh air.
Prince Andrew did not think that he was in love with Natásha; he was not thinking about her, but only picturing her to himself.
Prince Andrew saw all life appear in a new light.
Prince Andrew asked himself why he strives and toils in a narrow, confined frame while life with all its joys is open to him.
For the first time for a very long while, Prince Andrew began making happy plans for the future.
Prince Andrew decided that he must attend to his son’s education by finding a tutor and putting the boy in his charge.
Prince Andrew decided that he ought to retire from the service and go abroad, and see England, Switzerland and Italy.
Prince Andrew decided that he must use his freedom while he feels so much strength and youth in him.
Prince Andrew believed that one must believe in the possibility of happiness in order to be happy, and now he does believe in it.
Prince Andrew thought that the dead should bury their dead, but while one has life one must live and be happy.
One morning, Colonel Berg came to see Prince Andrew.
Colonel Berg was known to Pierre as he knew everybody in Moscow and Petersburg.
Colonel Berg arrived in an immaculate brand‑new uniform, with his hair pomaded and brushed forward over his temples as the Emperor Alexander wore his hair.
Colonel Berg said that he had just been to see the countess, Prince Andrew’s wife.
Colonel Berg said that unfortunately the countess could not grant his request.
Colonel Berg said that he hopes, Count, he shall be more fortunate with Prince Andrew.
Colonel Berg asked Prince Andrew what he wished.
Prince Andrew answered that he was at Colonel Berg’s service.
Colonel Berg said that he has now quite settled in his new rooms.
Colonel Berg said that he wishes to arrange a small party for his own and his wife’s friends.
Colonel Berg asked the countess and Prince Andrew to do him the honor of coming to tea and to supper.
